SpNote.note:
Four sequences are given below. The first, "Pol jitter then angle" is the most efficient, since three images are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved. This uses the recipe POL_JITTER.
The second sequence, "Pol angle then jitter", reverses the order in which the telescope and waveplate are moved. This time images at the 4 waveplate positions are obtained BEFORE the telescope is jittered. This involves more waveplate moves (and so is less efficient) though it does follow the "Golden Rule of Polarimetry" more closely. This uses the recipe POL_ANGLE_JITTER.
The third and forth sequences are used with extended sources (i.e. when blank sky cannot be extracted from the lower half of the array). The telescope is nodded between object and blank sky. In the forth MSB the sequence maps a 3x3 frame area on the sky with 50 per cent overlap. Data from each cycle are combined by the recipe POL_EXTENDED.
NOTE: All recipes require that separate flat-field observations be acquired before they are run. For longer wavelengths, use the "make_skyflat for Pol" sequences to take sky flats. Dome or twilight flats may be needed at shorter wavelengths or with narrow-band filters. Note that two skyflat sequences are available; the second obtains a separate flat at each of the four waveplate angles.
A dark with the same integration time as the object frames is also needed; this is included in the MSBs but needs to have its time defaulted in the usual way.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
SpNote.title: UFTI Imaging Polarimetry

SpNote.note:
Polarimetry observations of a compact or point source. The standard and target observations obtain a three jittered frames at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, 67.5 degrees).
Note - this MSB is the "inverse" of the "Pol angle then jitter" MSB since the jitter frames are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved.
Use with DR recipe POL_JITTER.
The MSB includes a standard star and a sky flat observation - a sky or dome flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark, for the pipeline to work.
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" sky flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using e.g. a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three E-W jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
SpNote.title: E-W jitter at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three E-W jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
SpNote.title: E-W jitter at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Polarimetry observations of a compact or point source. The standfard and target observations obtain images at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, 67.5 degrees) BEFORE the telescope is jittered.
Note - this sequence is less efficient than the "Pol jitter then angle" sequence, although it does obtain the necessary pol images more quickly (and thereby adheres more closely to the "Golden Rule of Polarimetry").
Use with the DR recipe POL_ANGLE_JITTER.
The MSB also includes a standfard star and a sky flat observation. Note, a separate dome or sky flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark, for the pipeline to work.
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged,regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, use the observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" (bottom of library) instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form a master sky flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_ANGLE_JITTER expects a frame at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees); these four frames are repeated at a number of East-West jitter positions. A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All four waveplate positions are observed before the telescope is moved.
N.B.: A dome or sky flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Jitter telescope positions three times after each set of four waveplate-offset frames are acquired. Offsets are 20-arcsecond steps E-W. There is also a 1-arcsecond N-S offset to sample different rows.
SpNote.title: Jitter AFTER 4 WP positions

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_ANGLE_JITTER expects a frame at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees); these four frames are repeated at a number of East-West jitter positions. A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All four waveplate positions are observed before the telescope is moved.
N.B.: A dome or sky flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Jitter telescope positions three times after each set of four waveplate-offset frames are acquired. Offsets are 20-arcsecond steps E-W. There is also a 1-arcsecond N-S offset to sample different rows.
SpNote.title: Jitter AFTER 4 WP positions

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
This MSB is for Pol imaging of an extended object that overlaps into the lower half of the UFTI array (i.e. is more than 30-40 arcsec in size). When this is the case, the lower e- and o-beam regions of each image cannot be used for blank sky brightness estimates; thus, separate blank sky frames must be acquired.
The sequence nods between object and blank sky at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees).
N.B. the MSB includes an (optional) standard star and a sky flat-field observation. A flat must have been obtained, as well as a Dark, for the DR to work.
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged,regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, use the observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" (bottom of library) instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form a master sky flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using e.g. a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three E-W jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_EXTENDED expects to receive eight frames for at least three jitter positions. The eight comprise pairs of object and sky exposures at each of the four waveplate positions. After each block of eight images the telescope is slightly jittered on the extended source to correct for bad pixels, etc.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three slightly jittered positions.
SpNote.title: Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
For Pol imaging of an extended object that overlaps into the lower half of the UFTI array (i.e. is more than 30-40 arcsec in size). When this is the case, the lower e- and o-beam regions of each image cannot be used for blank sky brightness estimates; thus, separate blank sky frames must be acquired.
The sequence maps a 3x3 frame target region with 50 per cent overlap, and nods between object and blank sky at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees).
This MSB includes an (optional) standard star observation and a sky flat observation. A separate flat-field must have been obtained, as well as a Dark, for the pipeline to work.
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged,regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, use the observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" (bottom of library) instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form a master sky flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using e.g. a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three E-W jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
SpNote.title: E-W jitter at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
POL_EXTENDED expects to receive eight frames for at least three jitter positions. The eight comprise pairs of object and sky exposures at each of the four waveplate positions. After each block of eight images the telescope is offset to map a larger area.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note:
Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three slightly jittered positions.
This set is akin to the 3x3 extended observation with 50% overlaps on the target and a jitter on a sky region.
SpNote.title: Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
AVAILABLE TEMPLATE SEQUENCES: ====================
Five sequences are given below.
The first, "Pol jitter then angle" is the most efficient, since three images are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved. This uses the recipe POL_JITTER.
The second sequence, "Pol angle then jitter", reverses the order in which the telescope and waveplate are moved. This time images at the 4 waveplate positions are obtained BEFORE the telescope is jittered. This involves more waveplate moves (and so is less efficient) though it does follow the "Golden Rule of Polarimetry" more closely. This uses the recipe POL_ANGLE_JITTER.
The third and forth sequences are used with extended sources (i.e. when blank sky cannot be extracted from the lower half of the array). The telescope is nodded between object and sky. In the forth sequence the telescope is offset east and west (by 15") to fill in the gap between the two pol aperture slices on the sky. 8 frames, consisting of an obj-sky pair at each of the 4 waveplate positions makes one cycle. Data from each cycle are combined by the recipe POL_EXTENDED.
The fifth sequence uses the coronagraphic polarimetry mask. The idea here is that bright targets can be observed with relatively long exposure times with the target behind one of two wires. The sequence of observations is essentially the same as for "pol jitter then angle", only the offsetting is different, with the target nudged up and down the wire. These sequence uses the recipe POL_JITTER_CORON (see MSB and/or IRPOL web pages for full details).
IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT POSN ANGLES: ========================
A position angle of -90 should be used for all imaging polarimetry EXCEPT when using the coronagraphic mask. Any angle between -90 and +90 may be used with the "coronagraphic imaging pol" MSB, though if you don't care, use -90. Offset along the rectangular mask are always in "p".
READOUT MODES ===========
We recommend using IRPOL CDS for all polarimetry observations. This allows for both long and very short (<1sec) exposure times. The former are useful for flat field and target observations; the latter are best for bright polarised/unpolarised standards. Obviously coadds can be used with short exposure times.
FLAT FIELDS =======
All DR recipes require that separate flat-field observations be acquired before they are run. For longer wavelengths, use the "make_skyflat for Pol" sequences to take sky flats. Dome or twilight flats may be needed at shorter wavelengths or with narrow-band filters. Note that two skyflat sequences are available; the second obtains a separate flat at each of the four waveplate angles.
A dark with the same integration time as the object frames is also needed; this is included in the MSBs but needs to have its time defaulted in the usual way.
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ===========================
These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
SpNote.title: UIST Imaging Polarimetry (Please read)

SpNote.note:
Polarimetry observations of a compact or point source. The sequence obtains a number of jittered frames at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, 67.5 degrees).
Note - this sequence is the "inverse" of the "Pol angle then jitter" sequence since the jitter frames are obtained BEFORE the waveplate is moved.
Use with POL_JITTER.
The MSB includes a standard star and a sky flat observations. A separate flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark, for the DR to work..

This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.

Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Sent for long, K-band exposures for a good flat-field. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).

SpNote.title: Back to zero

When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".

SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.

SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for short, K-band exposures on a bright standard. Make sure polarimetry is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_ANGLE_JITTER expects a frame at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees); these four frames are repeated at a number of North-South jitter positions. A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All four waveplate positions are observed before the telescope is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Jitter telescope positions three times after each set of four waveplate-offset frames are acquired. Offsets are 20-arcsecond steps N-S. There is also a 1-arcsecond E-W offset to sample different rows.
SpNote.title: Jitter AFTER 4 WP positions

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for shortish, K-band exposures on the target. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_ANGLE_JITTER expects a frame at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees); these four frames are repeated at a number of North-South jitter positions. A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All four waveplate positions are observed before the telescope is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Jitter telescope positions three times after each set of four waveplate-offset frames are acquired. Offsets are 20-arcsecond steps N-S. There is also a 1-arcsecond E-W offset to sample different rows.
SpNote.title: Jitter AFTER 4 WP positions

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
For Pol imaging of an extended object that overlaps into the lower half of the array (i.e. is more than 30-40 arcsec in size). When this is the case, the lower e- and o-beam regions of each image cannot be used for blank sky brightness estimates; thus, separate blank sky frames must be acquired.
The sequence nods between object and blank sky at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). The frames "on object" are slightly offset to account for bad pixels, etc.
The target observation is set up for three pairs of obj-sky pol observations, so 36 frames in total, but you could use more...
The MSB includes a standard star and a sky flat observations. A separate flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark, for the DR to work..
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Sent for long, K-band exposures for a good flat-field. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for short, K-band exposures on a bright standard. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three N-S jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
SpNote.title: N-S jitter at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Set for shortish, K-band exposures. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_EXTENDED expects to receive eight frames for at least three jitter positions. The eight comprise pairs of object and sky exposures at each of the four waveplate positions. After each block of eight images the telescope is slightly jittered on the extended source to correct for bad pixels, etc.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three slightly jittered positions.
SpNote.title: Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
For Pol imaging of an extended object that overlaps into the lower half of the array (i.e. is more than 30-40 arcsec in size). When this is the case, the lower e- and o-beam regions of each image cannot be used for blank sky brightness estimates; thus, separate blank sky frames must be acquired.
The sequence offsets east and west (by 15") to fill in the gap between the two pol aperture slices on the sky. From these data one may reconstruct a pol image over an area ~100" (E-W) by 120" (N-S). The offsets across the extended target are interspersed with blank sky frames, and of course every position (on object and on sky) is observed 4 times (at each WP position).
So thats: 4WP x 3 obj-sky pairs = 24 frames in total.
It may be worth repeating this sequence at slightly shifted "0,0" positions, to take account of bad pixels.
NOTE: This recipe/sequence has not been used before - PLEASE CHECK THE OFFSETS CAREFULLY!
The MSB includes a standard star and a sky flat observation. A separate flat must have been obtained, as well as a dark, for the DR to work..
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Sent for long, K-band exposures for a good flat-field. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for short, K-band exposures on a bright standard. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER expects an N-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). A typical usage would be to have three jitter positions giving twelve frames in all. All offsets positions are observed before the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (e.g. using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The three N-S jitter positions (20-arcsecond steps) are repeated for each of the four waveplate positions. The E-W jitter offsets can be changed in the "Offset iterator" below.
SpNote.title: N-S jitter at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for shortish, K-band exposures. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_EXTENDED expects to receive eight frames for at least three jitter positions. The eight comprise pairs of object and sky exposures at each of the four waveplate positions. After each block of eight images the telescope is slightly jittered on the extended source to correct for bad pixels, etc.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: Nod between object and blank sky for each of the four waveplate positions. Repeat this sequence at three E-W offset position chosen to fill in the gap between the pol-mask apertures positions.
SpNote.title: Obj-Sky pair at each WP position.

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees, and telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Set for long exposures for a good flat-field. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked and "coronograph" is selected.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, use the observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star (avoiding the waveplate holder), to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note:
Make sure polarimetry is ticked, the coronagraph is selected, and the exposure time is short (1sec usually). With the standard the same exposure time will be used for acquisition and for the actual pol imaging observations.
A posn angle of -90 gives the default orientation for UIST imaging, i.e. N left and E up. This is the default angle used with ordinary imaging polarimetry. Although any angle between -90 and +90 can be used with the coronagraphic mask, an angle between -90 and 0 will make imaging acquisition a little easier.
IF YOU DON'T CARE ABOUT THE ANGLE, USE -90 DEGREES !!!.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER_CORON expects an 3-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). All offset positions are observed BEFORE the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The 0,0 offset below is a trick we use to set-up imaging acquisition. You will acquire the target at the break immediately after this "offset".
SpNote.title: Dummy offset for acquisition

SpNote.note: The first dark below is a flush; the second dark provides a frame for dark-subtraction. Click "set default" in the dark to make sure it has the same exposure time and coadds as your observations of the standard.
SpNote.title: Darks

SpNote.note: To observe the standard OFF the wire, use offsets in "p" below. The offsets will be repeated for each of the four nominal waveplate angles.
SpNote.title: Offsets along wire at each WP angle

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it really only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star (avoiding the waveplate holder), to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note:
Make sure polarimetry is ticked, the coronograph is selected, and the exposure time is short (1sec usually) for IMAGING ACQUISITION. The exposure time for the actual observations is set later.
A posn angle of -90 gives the default orientation for UIST imaging, i.e. N left and E up. This is the default angle used with ordinary imaging polarimetry. Although any angle between -90 and +90 can be used with the coronographic mask, an angle between -90 and 0 will make imaging acquisition a little easier.
IF YOU DON'T CARE ABOUT THE ANGLE, USE -90 DEGREES !!!.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
POL_JITTER_CORON expects an 3-point jitter at each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). With the coronagraph the jitter positions are slight offsets along the wire. All offset positions are observed BEFORE the waveplate is moved.
N.B.: A flat field MUST be filed before this recipe is run (using a "make_skyflat..." observation). An appropriate dark must also be obtained.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe selection

SpNote.note: The 0,0 offset below is a trick we use to set-up imaging acquisition. You will acquire the target at the break immediately after this "offset".
SpNote.title: Dummy offset for acquisition

SpNote.note: The first dark below is a flush; the second dark provides a frame for dark-subtraction. It should have the same exposure time as used in the "UIST Imaging" iterator below, so in this case DON'T click on "set default"
SpNote.title: Darks

SpNote.note: Use the iterator below to set the exposure time (and coadds) needed for the actual coronagraphic imaging. These will be longer than the 1 or 2 secs used for the acquisition process above. 10-20 secs are recomended for 6-9th mag point sources and moderate seeing (0.6-0.7 arcsec).
SpNote.title: Uist iterator below

SpNote.note: Offsets should be in "q" (along the wire), and in multiples of 0.12 arcsec pixels. The offsets will be repeated for each of the four nominal waveplate angles.
SpNote.title: Offsets along wire at each WP angle

SpNote.note:
WHICH MSB Currently, template observations for point sources (sliding up and down the 20"-long spec-pol slits) and extended sources (nodding to blank sky) exist.
EXPOSURE TIMES For bright calibrators exposures of a few seconds work well.
For faint targets the following exposures are recommended with the 5 pixel spec-pol slit (for "near" background-limited performance):
>~300s for IJ, JH, shortJ, longJ, shortH, longH, shortK 240s for HK 60s for shortL 20s for longL 6s for M
SLIT ANGLES The default slit PA is -90 so that it matches the UIST imaging orientation (it makes imaging acquisition a bit simpler!), though any angle, between -90 and +90 (measured E of N) can be used.
ACQUISITION All targets (bright standards and faint sources) are now acquired in imaging mode. Simply make sure that each observation contains an acquisition Eyeball (see the examples below).
SpNote.title: UIST Spectro-Polarimetry

SpNote.note:
This MSB includes three observations, a flat/arc calibration, an (optional) standard star observation and a science target observation. Use the standard star observation to observe polarised or unpolarised standards, as well as flux/telluric standards where necessary.
All targets are assumed to be point sources. On the standard and science target an "object-sky" pair is observed at eight waveplate angles - 0,45,22.5,67.5 and 90,135,112.5,157.5 degs
OFFSETS: the slit length for spec-pol is only 20 arcseconds; thus 4.8 arcsec offsets up and down the slit are optimal (they should not be any larger).
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your standard star target co-ordinates below.
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations below UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component in the observation.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with an east-west 5 pixel pol slit. Select another grism, angle and/or slit from the drop down menus. Note that the POL option has also been ticked.
The waveplate is moved using an ITERATOR - i.e. waveplate moves are much like offsets on the sky; see the examples below.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using a UIST iterator) for the science target.
NOTE: If you change ANYTHING in the UIST component, open the "flat and arc " observation below, click on the flat eyeball and select "set default". Do the same on the arc. This ensures all changes are picked up by the calibrations.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: POINT_SOURCE_POL can be used on any point source; a polarised or unpolarised standard, or your science target. It assumes 8 object-sky pairs are acquired, one at each of the waveplate angles (0,45,22.5,67.5 and 90,135,112.5,157.5 degs).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 5sec x 3 coadds is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag (use coadds rather than one long exposure to avoid latency).
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below, and use the position editor to select a guide star (beware of vignetting from the waveplate holder)..
These coordinates will be used instead of the standard star coordinates.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: POINT_SOURCE_POL can be used on any point source; a polarised or unpolarised standard, or your science target. It assumes 8 object-sky pairs are acquired, one at each of the waveplate angles (0,45,22.5,67.5 and 90,135,112.5,157.5 degs).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 5sec x 3 coadds is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag (use coadds rather than one long exposure to avoid latency).
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note: Use the iterator below to update the exposure time for the science target (usually is longer).
SpNote.title: UIST spec-ifu iterator

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpMSB.title: Pol nod to blank sky (UIST - spectroscopy)

SpNote.note:
This MSB includes three observations, a flat/arc calibration, an (optional) standard star observation and a extended science target observation. Use the standard star observation to observe polarised or unpolarised standards, as well as flux/telluric standards where necessary.
The standard star is assumed to be a point source. The science target is assumed to be extended, i.e. equivalent to or larger than the 20-arcsec slit length. The standard is therefore slid up and down the spec-pol slit, while "object-sky" pairs on the science target involve offsets to blank sky.
In both cases an "object-sky" pair is observed at the eight waveplate angles - 0,45,22.5,67.5 and 90,135,112.5,157.5 degs.
SpNote.title: Aim of this MSB

SpNote.note:
Enter your standard star target co-ordinates below.
These coordinates will be inherited by the three observations below UNLESS they are over-written by a Target component in the observation.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note:
This example sets up the HK grism with an east-west 5 pixel pol slit. Select another grism, angle and/or slit from the drop down menus. Note that the POL option has also been ticked.
The waveplate is moved using an ITERATOR - i.e. waveplate moves are much like offsets on the sky; see the examples below.
These parameters will be inherited by the flat/arc, the standard, and the science target observations. Only the exposure time will be changed (using a UIST iterator) for the science target.
NOTE: If you change ANYTHING in the UIST component, open the "flat and arc " observation below, click on the flat eyeball and select "set default". Do the same on the arc. This ensures all changes are picked up by the calibrations.
SpNote.title: Configuration information

SpNote.note: POINT_SOURCE_POL can be used on any point source; a polarised or unpolarised standard, or your science target. It assumes 8 object-sky pairs are acquired, one at each of the waveplate angles (0,45,22.5,67.5 and 90,135,112.5,157.5 degs).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 5sec x 3 coadds is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag (use coadds rather than one long exposure to avoid latency).
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your science target co-ordinates below, and use the position editor to select a guide star (beware of vignetting from the waveplate holder)..
These coordinates will be used instead of the standard star coordinates.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Currenty we do not have a spectro-polarimetry recipe for extended sources. Use REDUCE_SINGLE_FRAME to get individual flat-field spectral images, for post-processsing with Polpack or TSP.
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: Use the observation below to select a short exposure time for imaging acquisition (depending on the source brightness). For standards, 1 sec should be enough; for faint science targets, 5sec x 3 coadds is usually ok for point sources down to about 17th mag (use coadds rather than one long exposure to avoid latency).
SpNote.title: Imaging Acquisition

SpNote.note: Use the iterator below to update the exposure time for the science target (usually is longer).
SpNote.title: UIST spec-ifu iterator

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note: Because the wollaston prism in CGS4 comes BEFORE the slit, spectro-polarimetry is EXTREMELY DIFFICULT with CGS4. We recommend using UIST unless absolutely necessary.
SpNote.title: CGS4

SpNote.note:
Simply takes a flat field and an arc lamp frame.
Be sure the CGS4 config matches that of your standard and target.
Be sure to hit the default button in the flat and arc editors if you change the configuration.
SpNote.title: Flat and Arc

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at http://www.jach.hawaii.edu/JACpublic/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/handbook.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your arcs and flats as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range -7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note:
You should select "prism" in the 'polariser' box. Note that with the prism, the slit is aligned to the prism rather than the array, so you will see sloping sky lines etc. in the data. The 2-pixel slit might be better aligned in terms of getting both the o- and e- polarimetry beams through the slit.
Best efforts are make to align all the slits, though obvioulsy it's more difficult to align the narrow (1 pixel) slit.
SpNote.title: cgs4+irpol

SpNote.note: POINT_SOURCE_POL can be used on any point source; a polarised or unpolarised standard, or your science target. It assumes 4 object-sky pairs are acquired, one at each of the nominal waveplate angles (0,45,22.5,67.5 degs).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: The offsets below nod the source 30 rows along the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This sequence interleaves irpol waveplate rotations and slit nodding.
The whole sequence looks like this:
Waveplate 0 degrees object1 object2 waveplate 45 degrees object2 object1 waveplate 22.5 degrees object1 object2 waveplate 67.5 degrees object2 object1
where object1 and object2 are two positions on the slit.
SpNote.title: irpol info

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
Enter your target co-ordinates into the target list below. Note that although this is called a "target list" it only allows you to specify ONE astronomical target.
When you have done so you can use the "position editor" to select a guide star, to fine tune the co-ordinate based on a sky survey picture, examine offset locations on the field etc.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note:
For detailed advice about CGS4 see the web page at http://www.jach.hawaii.edu/JACpublic/UKIRT/instruments/cgs4/handbook.html
Enter your desired CGS4 setup into the component below. Make sure you choose the same settings for grating, wavelength, order, slit width and position angle for your arcs and flats as for your sources.
Note that if you enter a central wavelength and choose a grating the order will be automatically selected. You may over-ride this if you wish, but seek advice on non-optimum orders from your support scientist.
There is feedback showing what the wavelength range and spectral resolution with the 1-pixel wide slit would be.
Enter the slit width in pixels that you want to use. Slit widths wider than 1-pixel may result in lower spectral resolution, depending on the seeing.
Slit position angles on the sky should fall in the range -7 to -173 degrees EAST of NORTH
If you select a source magnitude range the tool will enter a recommended exposure time and number of coadds at each sampling position. You may enter your own value instead if you prefer. If the exposure time is short (less than 1sec) consider using STARE mode instead.
Sampling is specified as "Oversampling factor" x "number of pixels" the spectrum is stepped over. So 2 x 2 sampling is Nyquist sampling stepped over 2 pixels giving a total of 4 independant measurements of the spectrum, 2 at each data point in the final spectrum.
SpNote.title: cgs4 setup

SpNote.note:
You should select "prism" in the 'polariser' box. Note that with the prism, the slit is aligned to the prism rather than the array, so you will see sloping sky lines etc. in the data. The 2-pixel slit might be better aligned in terms of getting both the o- and e- polarimetry beams through the slit.
Best efforts are make to align all the slits, though obvioulsy it's more difficult to align the narrow (1 pixel) slit.
SpNote.title: cgs4+irpol

SpNote.note: POINT_SOURCE_POL can be used on any point source; a polarised or unpolarised standard, or your science target. It assumes 4 object-sky pairs are acquired, one at each of the nominal waveplate angles (0,45,22.5,67.5 degs).
SpNote.title: DR Recipe Selection

SpNote.note: The offsets below nod the source 30 rows along the slit
SpNote.title: offset info

SpNote.note:
This sequence interleaves irpol waveplate rotations and slit nodding.
The whole sequence looks like this:
Waveplate 0 degrees object1 object2 waveplate 45 degrees object2 object1 waveplate 22.5 degrees object1 object2 waveplate 67.5 degrees object2 object1
where object1 and object2 are two positions on the slit.
SpNote.title: irpol info

SpNote.note: Waveplate back to 0 degrees. The last offset already sets the telescope back to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Return to zero

SpNote.note:
SITE QUALITY AND SCHEDULING CONSTRAINTS ------------------------------------------ These MSBs do not include site quality components; if you need these on an MSB-by-MSB basis then please add them from the component button once the MSBs are in your programme. If you have a global site quality requirement then this should be placed at the top of the programme and will apply to all the MSBs.
Scheduling constraints are also not included, since they are unlikely to apply to more than a small minority of programmes.
SpNote.title: Michelle

SpNote.note: These are *not* MSBs; they are individual observations that may be included within MSBs. Some already appear in the MSBs defined abobe, others (e.g. the make_skyflat for each WP angle) may be used as replacements.
SpNote.title: Utility sequences

SpObs.title: make_skyflat for each WP angle for Pol (UFTI)

SpNote.note:
Construct separate flat fields for each of the four waveplate angles. Any number of sky frames (five are used in this example) can be combined into each flat; the recipe SKY_FLAT_POL_ANGLE should be used.
N.B. All current polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
This recipe creates a flat field for each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). It requires frames consisting of at least three positions on the sky for each waveplate position, so that each group can be median averaged to form the flat.
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first.
If you do not need flats at each waveplate angle, select the observation "make_skyflat for Pol".
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" sky flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Remember to select the prism in the polariser box in the UFTI component below!
SpNote.title: Filter AND Prism

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead.
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note:
Observe at 8 different positions on the sky. Waveplate changed every 2 frames so that all 4 waveplate positions are sampled.
All eight frames median averaged to form flat field with SKY_FLAT_POL recipe. N.B.: Darks required by recipe.
SpNote.title: 2 positions x 4 WP positions.

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpObs.title: make_skyflat for each WP angle for Pol (UIST Imaging)

SpNote.note:
Construct separate flat fields for each of the four waveplate angles. Any number of sky frames can be combined into each flat (here five are used); the recipe SKY_FLAT_POL_ANGLE should be used.
N.B. All current polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field.
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: Target information

SpNote.note: Sent for long, K-band exposures for a good flat-field
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
This recipe creates a flat field for each of the four waveplate angles (0, 45, 22.5, and 67.5 degrees). It requires frames consisting of at least three positions on the sky for each waveplate position, so that each group can be median averaged to form the flat.
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first.
If you do not need flats at each waveplate angle, select the observation "make_skyflat for Pol".
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope to offset 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero

SpNote.note:
This sequence obtains eight frames, two at each waveplate angle, that are median averaged to make a "master" flat field for use with all subsequent target pol observations.
N.B. All current Polarimetry recipes require a separate flat field (and dark).
SpNote.title: Usage

SpNote.note:
Select a piece of blank sky near your target.
For a step-by-step guide to how to use the position editor use "help".
SpNote.title: target information

SpNote.note: Sent for long, K-band exposures for a good flat-field. Make sure the polarimetry box is ticked.
SpNote.title: UIST component

SpNote.note:
Recipe requires at least two frames at each of the 4 waveplate positions (0, 45, 22.5 and 67.5 degrees). All frames should be at different positions on blank sky. All frames are median averaged, regardless of the waveplate angle, to make a "master-pol-flat".
N.B.: A Dark MUST be obtained first. If you need separate flats for each waveplate position, select observation "make_skyflat for each WP angle" instead (see bottom of this library).
SpNote.title: Pol recipe

SpNote.note: Return waveplate to 0 degrees and the telescope offsets to 0,0.
SpNote.title: Back to zero
